quiz_summary: A mock test for NEET Physics covering 'Projectile Motion'. It includes 10 questions focusing on 2D motion, velocity resolution, maximum height, range, and time of flight based on the video transcript.

questions.question: What is the primary characteristic of projectile motion as defined in the lecture?

answerOptions.text: Motion in a straight vertical line.
answerOptions.rationale: Vertical motion is 1D; projectile motion is 2D at an angle.
Strictly horizontal motion is 1D.

answerOptions.text: Motion at some angle with the horizontal, resulting in a parabolic path.
answerOptions.rationale: The teacher defined projectile motion as a body thrown at an angle, moving under gravity in a parabolic path.

answerOptions.text: Motion outside the earth's gravitational field.
answerOptions.rationale: Projectile motion as discussed is near the earth's surface.

questions.hint: Recall the visual description of throwing an object at an angle.

questions.question: Why is it important that the projectile is 'near the earth'?

answerOptions.rationale: While air resistance is often ignored, the specific reason given was for a constant 'g'.

answerOptions.text: To ensure acceleration due to gravity (g) remains constant.
answerOptions.rationale: The teacher noted that 'g' is only constant near the earth's surface.

answerOptions.text: So that the range is not more than 100 meters.
answerOptions.rationale: The range can be kilometers, but 'g' must remain stable.

answerOptions.text: Because projectiles cannot fly at high altitudes.
answerOptions.rationale: They can, but the math changes if 'g' varies.

questions.hint: Think about the value of 'g' at different heights.

questions.question: The initial velocity vector $V_0$ at an angle $\theta$ can be resolved into:

answerOptions.rationale: The components are flipped; cos is horizontal if theta is with the horizontal.
As shown in the resolution diagram, the side adjacent to the angle is cos, and opposite is sin.
Tangents are not used for direct resolution into x and y vectors.
Velocity must be resolved into components.

questions.hint: Recall $V_x$ and $V_y$ expressions from the video.

questions.question: What is the acceleration along the x-axis (horizontal) in a standard projectile motion?

answerOptions.rationale: Gravity acts vertically.
The lecture states that since there is no horizontal force (ignoring air resistance), the acceleration $a_x = 0$.
Acceleration is independent of the projection angle.
This is the vertical acceleration.

questions.hint: Does gravity pull you sideways or downwards?

questions.question: At the maximum height of a projectile's path:

answerOptions.rationale: The horizontal velocity persists.

answerOptions.text: The vertical component of velocity ($V_y$) is 0.
answerOptions.rationale: At the peak, the object stops going up before it starts coming down, so $V_y = 0$.

answerOptions.text: The horizontal component of velocity ($V_x$) is 0.
answerOptions.rationale: $V_x$ is constant throughout the flight.
Acceleration $g$ acts throughout the motion.

questions.hint: What happens to the 'upward' motion at the very top?

questions.question: The velocity along the x-axis is considered ________ throughout the motion.

answerOptions.rationale: This would require a horizontal force.
Ignoring air resistance, it stays the same.
Since $a_x = 0$, the initial horizontal velocity ($V_x$) does not change.
It is predictable based on initial conditions.

questions.hint: Think about the expression 'no acceleration in x-axis'.

questions.question: The distance from the point of projection to the point where the particle lands is called the:

answerOptions.rationale: This is the peak vertical distance.
The horizontal distance traveled from start to finish is called the range.
This usually refers to the distance traveled along the actual trajectory.
Displacement is a vector, while range refers to the horizontal magnitude.

questions.hint: The teacher called the distance from O to A 'the _______'.

questions.question: The vertical acceleration acting on the projectile is represented as:

answerOptions.rationale: Gravity acts downwards.
The lecture uses 'minus j' to indicate the downward direction of gravity.
'i' represents the x-axis.
Gravity provides acceleration in the y-axis.

questions.hint: Which unit vector corresponds to the vertical axis?

questions.question: The duration for which the particle remains in the air is known as:

answerOptions.rationale: Not a standard term.
This is the standard term for the total time spent in the air.
This usually refers to time taken to reach maximum height.
Not a standard term.

questions.hint: Look at the very last point mentioned in the transcript.

questions.question: If a body is thrown vertically upwards, its horizontal velocity component is:

answerOptions.rationale: Only if thrown horizontally.
Vertical motion has an angle $\theta = 90^\circ$ with the horizontal ($ \cos 90^\circ = 0 $).
It is actually minimum (zero).
G is acceleration, not velocity.

questions.hint: The teacher contrasted this with horizontal and angular throws at the start.

encouragement: Great job! You now have a solid understanding of the kinematics of projectile motion.
